awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Surface Spectroscopic Investigations into the Molecular Mechanism Governing Cell Membrane Repair
awd_abstract_narration:
Andrew P. Carpenter is awarded a FY21 Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research (NSF MPS-Ascend) Fellowship to conduct a program of research and activities related to broadening participation by groups underrepresented in Chemistry at Oregon State University.  The project being performed by Andrew Carpenter, entitled Nonlinear Surface Spectroscopic Investigations into the Molecular Mechanism Governing Cell Membrane Repair, is to be conducted under the guidance of mentoring scientist Joe Baio.  This project is supported by the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities and the Chemistry Division in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and by the Molecular Biophysics Program of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division of the Biological Sciences Directorate.

Membrane-bound proteins carry out many cellular functions, including repair of tears in the cellular plasma membrane.  This process is not well understood, and this project will utilize vibrational sum-frequency generation (VSF) spectroscopy to investigate the mechanism governing membrane repair by the specific protein dysferlin, including determining the phospholipids that dysferlin binds at membrane surfaces to initiate the membrane repair process, elucidating the membrane packing conditions necessary for dysferlin binding, directly interrogating dysferlin at vesicle surfaces using VSF scattering spectroscopy, and establishing experimental and computational methodology needed to extract structural information from VSF spectra of multi-domain proteins. Broadening participation of Native Americans in science, technology, math and engineering will be supported by partnering with efforts at Oregon State University that focus on providing research opportunities and targeted STEM outreach events for students and teachers from the local Chemawa Indian school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background

This postdoctoral fellowship supported work seeking to use nonlinear spectroscopic methods to understand the molecular origins of Dysferlinopathies, a specific subset of adult-onset muscular dystrophy connected to the protein Dysferlin. The primary nonlinear spectroscopic method at the heart of this work, vibrational sum-frequency (VSF) spectroscopy, measures the vibrational spectrum of molecules at interfaces, the boundary between two phases. Specific Dysferlin domains, primarily the C2A domain (dysC2A) were exposed to biomimetic membrane surfaces (lipid monolayers and vesicles) and VSF was used to characterize the domain structure and orientation. From VSF spectra the manner in which wild-type dysferlin binds to lipid surfaces was characterized before turning to study how specific missense mutations break the wild-type membrane binding chemistry.

 

Intellectual Merit

Early VSF experiments found wild-type dysC2A interacted with membrane surfaces in a lipid-dependent fashion. Experimental VSF spectra were matched to simulated spectra, using established computational methods, revealing dysC2A had two lipid binding modes. For most anionic membrane surfaces dysC2A inserts its calcium binding loops into the membrane surface and orients the primary domain axis 30-40˚ from interfacial normal. This binding geometry is similar to how other C2 protein domains interact with anionic membranes, thus it is referred to as a “generic binding orientation”. When the lipid PI(4,5)P2 was added to the lipid membrane, changes in VSF signal indicated a shift in dysC2A orientation. Simulated spectra revealed dysC2A adjusts its orientation, so the primary domain axis is >60˚ from interfacial normal. This orientation positions a polybasic region of amino acids near the lipid surface. Additional experiments found this region of the protein domain coordinates the PI(4,5)P2 headgroup, and it was subsequently shown the interfacial reorientation in response to PI(4,5)P2 is preferred over the generic binding orientation. This membrane binding orientation is referred to as a “PI(4,5)P2 specific binding orientation”.

Having characterized its wild-type membrane binding chemistry, dysC2A was selectively mutated with pathogenic and non-pathogenic missense mutations. The distinguishing factor is whether the specific mutation has been identified in a clinical case of limb-girdle type 2B or Myoshi myopathy muscular dystrophy. Using VSF to monitor the spectral signatures of the two dysC2A binding orientations it was found the non-pathogenic variants caused either (i) a disruption to the membrane binding calcium dependence or (ii) eliminated the PI(4,5)P2 specific binding interaction. Pathogenic variants proved difficult to express and/or purify via recombinant protein synthesis. Variations in the expression conditions suggest the pathogenic dysC2A variants are destabilized by the missense mutations and aggregate inside inclusion bodies. Thus, it is hypothesized that cases of Dysferlinopathies linked to mutations within the dysC2A domain are the result of a destabilized protein domain that induces aggregation and prevents wild-type membrane binding function. While further work is required to confirm this, molecular dynamics simulations find these pathogenic mutations destabilize the dysC2A structure, supporting this hypothesis.

Additional, early, experiments suggest VSF spectroscopy can be applied to the study of multi-domain constructs. VSF signal was detected from a C2A-C2B multi-domain construct interacting with a PI(4,5)P2 surface. Additional simulation/analysis methods still need to be developed to recover individual domain orientation information. However, once done, the application of VSF spectroscopy provides an avenue to study inter-domain protein interactions, opening a door to the use of this experimental method to the study of much larger and more complicated proteins.

This fellowship also supported the PI in environmental focused collaborations, where VSF spectroscopy was used to correlate nanoparticle toxicity to nanoparticle-membrane interactions and the adsorption of PFAS to environmental surfaces.

 

Broader Impacts

The primary broader impact goal was to partner with the sponsoring scientist to engage teachers at the local Chemawa Indian School. Unfortunately, in part due to down-stream effects from the Covid pandemic, this engagement was not able to be carried out.

As a result, the PI focused their attention on providing support to graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in the chemical, biological, and environmental engineering fields. The PI developed a writing group to aid the development of scientific communication skills of engineering graduate students and participated in informal mentorship efforts. The PI also formally mentored 4 undergraduate students, two of which were matched with the PI through a university program purposed at introducing first-generation undergraduates to STEM research in their first year of college.
